prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 1".
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in IRAS 17208-0014. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.5 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=1-0 observations of Downes & Solomon (1998) to estimate the sensitivity we need to detect the source. IRAS 17208-0014 is very compact and we assume it is a point source. The peak intensity of the 12CO J=1-0 is ~200 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 22 (Aalto et al. 1995) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=1-0 peak intensity of ~9 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 15 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 1".
Correlator Setup: We will use band 7 to observe 13CO J=3-2 in IRAS 17208-0014. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1.9 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=3-2 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) to estimate the required sensitivity to detect the source. The peak intensity if ~400 mJy in 12CO J=3-2. We use a line ratio of 12CO/13CO = 43 (Greve et al. 2009) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=3-2 peak intensity of ~9 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy at a spectral resolution of 20 km/s for a 10 sigma detection of the line.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 0.8”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 7 to observe 13CO J=3-2 in IRAS 10565+2448. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~1.8 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=3-2 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) to estimate the required sensitivity to detect the source. The peak intensity if ~400 mJy in 12CO J=3-2. We use a line ratio of 12CO/13CO = 43 (Greve et al. 2009) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=3-2 peak intensity of ~9 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy at a spectral resolution of 20 km/s for a 10 sigma detection of the line.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 0.8".
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in IRAS 10565+2448. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.5 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=1-0 observations of Downes & Solomon (1998) to estimate the sensitivity we need to detect the source. We assume IRAS 10565+2448 is a point source. The peak intensity of the 12CO J=1-0 is ~150 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 22 (Aalto et al. 1995) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=1-0 peak intensity of ~7 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.7 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 15 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 2.1”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in Arp 193. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.4 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=1-0 observations of Downes & Solomon (1998) to estimate the sensitivity we need to detect the source. The peak intensity of the 12CO J=1-0 is ~200 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 22 (Aalto et al. 1995) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=1-0 peak intensity of ~9 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 15 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 2.1”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=2-1 in Arp 193. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~2.7 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=2-1 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=2-1 observations of Downes & Solomon (1998) to estimate the sensitivity we need to detect the source. The peak intensity of the 12CO J=1-0 is ~200 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 33 (e.g. Sliwa et al. 2013) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=2-1 peak intensity of ~6 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.6 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 20 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 1.5”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in NGC 6240. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.4 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: Papadopoulos et al. (2012) observed NGC 6240 in 13CO J=1-0 and J=2-1 using single dish telescopes. The total flux of 13CO J=1-0 was measured to be 6.5 Jy km/s. Iono et al. (2009) measured the FWHM of the CO line in NGC 6240 to be 500 km/s. To be conservative, we assume the line profile is rectangular; therefore, we estimate the 13CO J=1-0 peak to be 13 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 1 mJy for a ~13 sigma detection for a spectral resolution of 10 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 1.5”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=2-1 in NGC 6240. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~2.7km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=2-1 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use 12CO J=2-1 observations of NGC 6240 (Tacconi et al. 1999) to estimate the sensitivity required to detect the source. The peak intensity of 12CO J=2-1 is found to be 400 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 33 (e.g. Sliwa et al. 2013) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=2-1 peak intensity of ~12 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 1.2 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 5 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 2.1”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 3 to observe 13CO J=1-0 in NGC 2623. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~5.4 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=1-0 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=1-0 observations of Bryant & Scoville (1999) of NGC 2623 to estimate a sensitivity. The peak of the 12CO J=1-0 is ~220 mJy; however, the resolution of Bryant & Scoville (1999) is slightly poorer (~2.9”) than the one we request, therefore, we assume the emission is uniform over the beam and estimate the peak of 12CO J=1-0 in the 2.1” to be 115 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 22 (Aalto et al. 1995) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=1-0 peak intensity of ~5.3 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.53 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 25 km/s.

Angular resolution: We would like to match the resolution of the CO J=3-2 observations of Wilson et al. (2008) in order to study the molecular gas on similar spatial scales. We request an angular resolution of 2.1”.
Correlator Setup: We will use band 6 to observe 13CO J=2-1 in NGC 2623. We require the widest bandwidth mode (1.875 GHz) for each of the 4 spectral windows. To decrease the data rate, we will use a spectral averaging factor of 4, which will slightly decrease the spectral resolution to ~2.7 km/s. One spectral window will be centered on 13CO J=2-1 and the remaining 3 spectral windows will be used to measure the continuum. We use a fine spectral resolution for the continuum spectral windows in case there are any unexpected spectral lines detected.
Sensitivity: We use the 12CO J=2-1 observations of Wilson et al. (1998) to estimate the sensitivity we need to detect the source. The peak intensity of the 12CO J=2-1 is ~300 mJy. We assume a line of 12CO/13CO J=1-0 of 33 (e.g. Sliwa et al. 2013) in Jy units which gives us a 13CO J=2-1 peak intensity of ~9 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 0.9 mJy for a 10 sigma detection at a spectral resolution of 10 km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs) are observed to have weak 13CO emission. The observed 12CO/13CO line ratios are greater than 2 times that what is observed in our Galaxy. The a large 12CO-to-13CO abundance ratio ([12CO]/[13CO]) has been suggested as the cause of the unsual 12CO/13CO line ratios. VV 114, a local LIRG, has been shown to have a large [12CO]/[13CO] ratio, about 5 times larger than what is observed in our Galaxy. We propose to observe a sample of five LIRGs, each in two 13CO lines. We will do a Bayesian likelihood radiative transfer analysis to determine whether large [12CO]/[13CO] ratios are common in LIRGs.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
